content.p: Length (in days) of human pregnancies is a normal random variable (X) with mean 266, standard deviation 16.

(It would be useful to sketch this normal distribution yourself, marking its mean and the values that are 1, 2, and 3 standard deviations below and above the mean. Click here to compare your figure to ours.)

body.p: The probability is 0.95 that a pregnancy will last between and days.
The shortest 16% of pregnancies last less than days.
The probability of a pregnancy lasting longer than 314 days is .
There is a probability of 0.5 that a pregnancy will last longer than days.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Recall that with probability 0.95, a normal random variable will get values that are between 2 standard deviations below the mean and 2 standard deviations above the mean.

Correct. With probability 0.95, a normal random variable will get values that are between 2 standard deviations below the mean (266 − 2 * 16 = 234) and 2 standard deviations above the mean (266 + 2 * 16 = 298).
Incorrect. Recall that with probability 0.95, a normal random variable will get values that are between 2 standard deviations below the mean and 2 standard deviations above the mean.

Correct. With probability 0.95, a normal random variable will get values that are between 2 standard deviations below the mean (266 − 2 * 16 = 234) and 2 standard deviations above the mean (266 + 2 * 16 = 298).
Incorrect. Recall that with probability 0.95, a normal random variable will get values that are between 2 standard deviations below the mean and 2 standard deviations above the mean.
Incorrect. Note that 68% of pregnancies last between 250 and 282 days. The remaining 32% of pregnancies must be in the two tails together: either less than 250 days or more than 282 days.
Incorrect. Note that 68% of pregnancies last between 250 and 282 days. The remaining 32% of pregnancies must be in the two tails together: either less than 250 days or more than 282 days.
Correct. Sixteen percent of pregnancies last less than 1 standard deviation below the mean, which in this case is 266 − 16 = 250.
Incorrect. Note that 68% of pregnancies last between 250 and 282 days. The remaining 32% of pregnancies must be in the two tails together: either less than 250 days or more than 282 days.
Incorrect. Note that 68% of pregnancies last between 250 and 282 days. The remaining 32% of pregnancies must be in the two tails together: either less than 250 days or more than 282 days.
Incorrect. Note that 68% of pregnancies last between 250 and 282 days. The remaining 32% of pregnancies must be in the two tails together: either less than 250 days or more than 282 days.
Incorrect. Note that 68% of pregnancies last between 250 and 282 days. The remaining 32% of pregnancies must be in the two tails together: either less than 250 days or more than 282 days.

Incorrect. Note from the figure that it is extremely unlikely for a pregnancy to last more than 314 days. More specifically, there is a probability of 0.997 that a pregnancy will last between 218 and 314 days. This means that there is 1 − 0.997 = 0.003 probability that the length of the pregnancy will be in the two tails: either less than 218 days or more than 314 days.

Incorrect. This value does not divide the area under the curve into two halves.
Incorrect. This value does not divide the area under the curve into two halves.
Incorrect. This value does not divide the area under the curve into two halves.

Correct. The value that divides the area under the curve into two halves is 266, so P(X < 266) = P(X > 266) = 0.5. A pregnancy is as likely to last less than 266 days as it is to last more than 266 days.
